I thought this was just a neat little story that showed how big a little dogs heart can be... 
 
 Tiny dog saves baby from rattlesnake
 Sun Jul 22, 3:24 PM ET
 Zoey is a Chihuahua, but when a rattlesnake lunged at her owners' 1-year-old grandson, she was a real bulldog.
 
 Booker West was splashing his hands in a birdbath in his grandparents' northern Colorado back yard when the snake slithered up to the toddler, rattled and struck. Five-pound Zoey jumped in the way and took the bites.
 
 "She got in between Booker and the snake, and that's when I heard her yipe," Monty Long, the boy's grandfather, said Thursday.
 
 The dog required treatment and for a time it appeared she might not survive the bites she suffered earlier this month. Now she prances about.
 
 "These little bitty dogs, they just don't really get credit," Booker's grandma Denise Long told the Loveland Daily Reporter-Herald.

post_info.post_title: A Touching Story About An Incredible Dog:

I saw this little guy on the News this morning. He was laying on the Grandmothers lap with his eyes closed as she gently stroked him during her interview about his heroic and selfless act with the Rattle Snake. As he raised his little head up you could see the sense of satisfaction and pride on his cute little face as if he knew he was an incredibly brave hero. emoticon_xlove

What a waste of type space. 
 
 A chihuahua is a terrier. Terriers kill rats, mice, and snakes. As far as I know, that is the only reason we allow them to continue consuming oxygen. 
 
 Entirely out of curiosity, what did you city folks think those annoying little dogs with the unusually high tolerance to snake venom (one of my german shepherds was bitten by a rattlesnake last year and nearly died. My rat terrier was bitten at least 20 times in one week this summer, and was sick for a couple of days) were for?

That's dogs for you. Doesn't matter the size of the dog, they all have the same size heart (metaphorically speaking). Sometimes I think small dogs try too hard (some sort of Napolean complex).
 
 I bet a cat wouldn't have bothered.
 
 A real shame my wife doesn't trust dogs. (Maybe I could trade her in for a german shepherd).

What a waste of type space. 
 
 A chihuahua is a terrier. Terriers kill rats, mice, and snakes. As far as I know, that is the only reason we allow them to continue consuming oxygen. 
 
 Entirely out of curiosity, what did you city folks think those annoying little dogs with the unusually high tolerance to snake venom (one of my german shepherds was bitten by a rattlesnake last year and nearly died. My rat terrier was bitten at least 20 times in one week this summer, and was sick for a couple of days) were for?

 
 Are you saying that the OP is a waste of type space because Terriers are mousers ? What about the fact that they're cute and make great pets ? I'm a little shocked at your attitude, especially since the article doesn't even say the dog attempted to attack the snake but simply placed himself between the snake and the child. A more heroic and selfless act is difficult to imagine. Do you really think that that little dog reasoned in advance that, well, I was built to get bitten by a Rattler, even though their bites have killed animals 20 times my weight, I know I can take it so here I go ? Pretty cold hearted deawoo, and totally misses the point of the thread, which was just to praise a brave little dog who pretty much definitely saved the life of a toddler who's chances of surviving that bite was slim to none.

I agree with Daewoo. 
 More than a little anthropomorphizing, I think.
 
 I love dogs; they are wonderful. I agree they're cute and make great pets. 
 But what happened was neither brave, heroic, selfless nor showed how much "heart" the dog had. He was acting like a dog, doing what his breed does. Also, no one but the one-year-old actually saw what happened. 
 
 Similarly, a cat couldn't be bothered because they are cats and act like cats.

I'm not quite ready to attribute heroic motives to a dog who probably has an instinct to snap at small animals. And I'm a dog lover. This is one of those feel good stories the media likes to jump on. Not that there's anything wrong with that.
 
 And that look that suggested satisfaction was probably the result of some heavy duty pain meds.

Are you saying that the OP is a waste of type space because Terriers are mousers ? What about the fact that they're cute and make great pets ? I'm a little shocked at your attitude, especially since the article doesn't even say the dog attempted to attack the snake but simply placed himself between the snake and the child. A more heroic and selfless act is difficult to imagine. Do you really think that that little dog reasoned in advance that, well, I was built to get bitten by a Rattler, even though their bites have killed animals 20 times my weight, I know I can take it so here I go ? Pretty cold hearted deawoo, and totally misses the point of the thread, which was just to praise a brave little dog who pretty much definitely saved the life of a toddler who's chances of surviving that bite was slim to none.

 I'm not quite sure I understand your point here. You call the dog heroic and selfless which would imply that he knew there was danger and responded to protect the child. Without the ability to reason in advance, did the dog somehow magically know that the snake was going to bite the child? Did the dog evaluate the situation and think 'hmm...the kid could get hurt, I might want to jump in and do something to prevent that? 
 
 More than likely, the dog was attracted by the rattle of the snake, and as such went to investigate the noise and upon finding the snake, attacked it out of instinct. It's just what they do.
 
 Calling the dog heroic and selfless is rediculous in the aspect that you would have to conclude that the dog knew the danger to itself, and acted anyway. Not likely. I'm sure the dog is not educated in the dangers of poisonous snakes. 
 
 And for the record, daewoo in no way suggested that the dog reasoned about being able to withstand the venom due to it's high tolerance to it. He simply stated a fact, that they have a high tolerance to snake venom. The fact that they have a high tolerance for snake venom is another issue all together. Call it ev...err...an adaptation if you will.

Are you saying that the OP is a waste of type space because Terriers are mousers ? What about the fact that they're cute and make great pets ? I'm a little shocked at your attitude, especially since the article doesn't even say the dog attempted to attack the snake but simply placed himself between the snake and the child. A more heroic and selfless act is difficult to imagine. Do you really think that that little dog reasoned in advance that, well, I was built to get bitten by a Rattler, even though their bites have killed animals 20 times my weight, I know I can take it so here I go ? Pretty cold hearted deawoo, and totally misses the point of the thread, which was just to praise a brave little dog who pretty much definitely saved the life of a toddler who's chances of surviving that bite was slim to none.

 
 Others have summed it up pretty well. Your argument here is an interesting one. You seem to be attemtping to debunk my post by implying that I belieive the dog reasoned ahead of time that it was immune to the poison and (rightly) you scoff at that idea. Then you seem to hinge your argument on the idea that the dog reasoned ahead of time that the snake not only posed a threat, but posed a mortal threat to the infant. 
 
 Now, back in the real world, unless the dog had been bitten by a rattlesnake before, it had NO IDEA that the snake was dangerous. There is a better than average chance that, being a city dog, it had NO IDEA what a snake was. Even though it had no idea what it was, its instinct would have been to kill it. 
 
 As far as what exactly the dog saved the baby from...it was probably not so much a horrible death as it was an annoying stinging sensation and a small to moderate amount of uncomfortable swelling. It is pretty unusual for somebody to die of a snakebite...even if they get no treatment...and dying from a bite from a prairie rattle snake or a timber rattler is virtually unheard of. I have been bitten by a prairie rattlers on numerous occasions, as have most others around here who gather hay (the snakes are often found under hay bales in the field and strike when you lift the bale) and the result is a swollen area on my leg. Unless the individual is allergic to the venom (as some people are to bee venom) prairie rattlers and timber rattlers jsut aren't all that dangerous. If they ARE allergic to the venom they can go into anaphylactic shock, in which case an injection of ephinepherine is warranted. A snake enom allergy is EXTREMELY rare, though. I have never seen one, nor have I ever heard a first person report of an individual having one. 
 
 So basically....we are back to the story. A terrier killed a snake...which is what terriers do.

As far as what exactly the dog saved the baby from...it was probably not so much a horrible death as it was an annoying stinging sensation and a small to moderate amount of uncomfortable swelling. It is pretty unusual for somebody to die of a snakebite...even if they get no treatment...and dying from a bite from a prairie rattle snake or a timber rattler is virtually unheard of. I have been bitten by a prairie rattlers on numerous occasions, as have most others around here who gather hay (the snakes are often found under hay bales in the field and strike when you lift the bale) and the result is a swollen area on my leg. Unless the individual is allergic to the venom (as some people are to bee venom) prairie rattlers and timber rattlers jsut aren't all that dangerous. If they ARE allergic to the venom they can go into anaphylactic shock, in which case an injection of ephinepherine is warranted. A snake enom allergy is EXTREMELY rare, though. I have never seen one, nor have I ever heard a first person report of an individual having one.

 I'm an Irish Wolfhound person.

 Anything small as a this dog is simply a food animal.

My local variety are a bit more fearsome:http://digital-desert.com/wildlife/mojave-green-rattlesnake.html

 
 Your definition of "a bit" and mine are apparently quit different :)
 
 IMO the only 2 rattlesnakes you actually have to worry about in the US are the mojave and the eastern diamondback. The sidewinder is actually more poisonous than the eastern diamondback, but they do not release venom when they bite defensively, and the eastern diamondbacks poison is not that potent, but it produces a LOT of it...enough to kill easily.
 
 IIRC the poison from the mojave is roughly as potent as that of the cottonmouth, which is to say pretty damn deadly.

Ditto.
 
 I'm an Irish Wolfhound person.
 Currently have a Great Dane puppy (after having to put the old hound down).
 
 Anything small as a this dog is simply a food animal.

 Is this your first Dane? 
 
 I have a Great Dane myself. I absolutely love big dogs, and GD's are fantastic. 
 
 2 things to beware of:
 
 They eat a lot. So much in fact, my wife and I wanted to write our Dane off on our taxes (the accountant said no). 
 
 As a result of all the eating....they poop a lot. As long as you don't mind a few 5lb piles, you should be ok.

 Currently have a Great Dane puppy (after having to put the old hound down).
 
 Anything small as a this dog is simply a food animal.

 
 I keep german shepherds. I do try to keep a terrier around for rat, mouse, and snake control.
 
 You guys with big dogs and kids have got to get one of these:
 
 http://www.k9carting.com/carts.html
 
 My kids LOVE it and the dogs seem to think it is a blast. The dogs always get excited when I pull it out of the barn and line up to be hitched up. I use the double team hitch and the kids (and dogs) traila long when I go horseback riding.

 My GD would probably fall over at the sight of the thing. Anything that interupts her 20 hour nap is strictly verboten. My Shar Pei on the other hand would probably love it.

My GD would probably fall over at the sight of the thing. Anything that interupts her 20 hour nap is strictly verboten. My Shar Pei on the other hand would probably love it.

 
 LMAO. My sister used to have a mastiff that was like that. All it ever did was sleep. She used to joke that the only way she knew the dog wasn't dead was that 10 lbs of food would dissapear every day. She claimed it was her guard dog. I told her that she could probably get rid of the dog and just keep the 2 huge food dishes by hte back door and it would be jsut as effective...the dog was just an expensive to feed trip hazard.

Is this your first Dane? 
 
 I have a Great Dane myself. I absolutely love big dogs, and GD's are fantastic. 
 
 2 things to beware of:
 
 They eat a lot. So much in fact, my wife and I wanted to write our Dane off on our taxes (the accountant said no). 
 
 As a result of all the eating....they poop a lot. As long as you don't mind a few 5lb piles, you should be ok.

 
 Yep, 1st Dane but we've owned a Wolfhoud before.
 The dane is very hyperactive compared to the wolfhound. I'm hoping she calms down by the time she's fully grown.
 
 I've also given up on the back yard. I was hoping to reclaim it when we lost the hound but...

Having had dogs for years - and currently with two Dachshund/Yorkshire Terrier crosses - I know what big-hearted means, I know what affectionate means, and I know what breed instinct means.
 
 Had it been a movie, the chihuahua's actions would have been portrayed as selfless in saving the kiddie's life. In reality, the dog happened to be in the wrong place (for the dog) at the right time (for the child). It probably didn't attack the snake, just stood there yapping as chihuahuas are prone to do.
 
 It makes a nice warming news story, but needs taking with a large dose of salt. ;)
